description: From Old French convertir, from Latin converto (“turn around”).

entries.meaning: A person who has converted to a religion.
examples: They were all converts to Islam.

entries.meaning: A person who is now in favour of something that he or she previously opposed or disliked.
examples: I never really liked broccoli before, but now that I've tasted it the way you cook it, I'm a convert!

entries.meaning: (Canadian football) The equivalent of a conversion in rugby

verbs.description: convert (third-person singular simple present converts, present participle converting, simple past and past participle converted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To transform or change (something) into another form, substance, state, or product.
examples: A kettle converts water into steam.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To change (something) from one use, function, or purpose to another.
examples: He converted his garden into a tennis court.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To induce (someone) to adopt a particular religion, faith, ideology or belief (see also sense 11).
examples: They converted her to Roman Catholicism on her deathbed.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To exchange for something of equal value.
examples: We converted our pounds into euros.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To express (a quantity) in alternative units.
(transitive) To express (a unit of measurement) in terms of another; to furnish a mathematical formula by which a quantity, expressed in the former unit, may be given in the latter.
examples: How do you convert feet into metres?

entries.meaning: (transitive, law) To appropriate wrongfully or unlawfully; to commit the common law tort of conversion.
(transitive, intransitive, rugby football) To score extra points after (a try) by completing a conversion.
(transitive or intransitive, soccer) To score (especially a penalty kick).
(intransitive, ten-pin bowling) To score a spare.
(intransitive) To undergo a conversion of religion, faith or belief (see also sense 3).
(intransitive) To become converted.
examples: The chair converts into a bed.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To cause to turn; to turn.
examples: O, which way shall I first convert myself?

entries.meaning: (transitive, logic) To change (one proposition) into another, so that what was the subject of the first becomes the predicate of the second.
(transitive, obsolete) To turn into another language; to translate.
examples: which story […] Catullus more elegantly converted

entries.meaning: (transitive, cricket) To increase one's individual score, especially from 50 runs (a fifty) to 100 runs (a century), or from a century to a double or triple century.
examples: Gillespie was reminded he had promised to join team-mate Matthew Hayden in a nude lap of the ground if he converted his century into a double.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, marketing) To perform the action that an online advertisement is intended to induce; to reach the point of conversion.
examples: Each time a user clicks on one of your adverts, you will be charged the bid amount whether the user converts or not.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, chess) To transform a material or positional advantage into a win.
